verses.text: Then Eliashib the high priest rose up with his brothers the priests, and they built the Sheep Gate. They consecrated it and set up its doors; and they consecrated it as far as the Tower of the Hundred and as far as the Tower of Hananel.
verses.comment: The mention of 'consecration' reflects the sacredness of the work. The high priest leading the people is a foreshadowing of Christ as the ultimate High Priest (Heb. 4:14).

verses.text: Next to him the men of Jericho built. And next to them Zaccur the son of Imri built.
verses.comment: The cooperative effort of different groups illustrates the unity of God’s people in His work. This hints at the importance of working together in building the one Church.

verses.text: The sons of Hassenaah built the Fish Gate. They laid its beams and set up its doors, its bolts, and its bars.
verses.comment: Meticulous care is given to the gates—a sign of divine order and attention to detail, reminiscent of instructions given to Moses for the tabernacle (Exod. 26).

verses.text: Next to them Meremoth the son of Uriah, son of Hakkoz repaired. Next to them Meshullam the son of Berechiah, son of Meshezabel repaired. And next to them Zadok the son of Baana repaired.
verses.comment: Family lines and priestly connections are emphasized, indicating the importance of tradition and proper lineage in the work of God.

verses.text: Next to them the Tekoites repaired; but their nobles did not put their shoulders to the work of their Lord.
verses.comment: Some resisted the work even among God’s people, a reminder that obedience and service is not always universal (see Matt. 21:28–32).

verses.text: Joiada the son of Paseah and Meshullam the son of Besodeiah repaired the Old Gate; they laid its beams and set up its doors, its bolts, and its bars.
verses.comment: The detailed construction continues to highlight the sacred duty and unity in rebuilding the city, foreshadowing the spiritual rebuilding described in the New Testament community.

verses.text: Next to them Melatiah the Gibeonite and Jadon the Meronothite, the men of Gibeon and of Mizpah, repaired the seat of the governor of the region Beyond the River.
verses.comment: Jews from outside Jerusalem participate, showing the inclusion of all God’s people. The governor refers to the Persian-appointed ruler, reflecting the community’s place within a larger nation.

verses.text: Next to them Uzziel the son of Harhaiah, one of the goldsmiths, repaired. Next to him Hananiah, one of the perfumers, repaired, and they restored Jerusalem as far as the Broad Wall.
verses.comment: Guilds and artisans join, symbolizing the participation of every vocation in sacred work. Everyone has a role in the life and restoration of God’s people.

verses.text: Next to them Rephaiah the son of Hur, leader of half the district of Jerusalem, repaired.
verses.comment: Even civil rulers take part, showing the collaboration of spiritual and temporal authority in God's plan.

verses.text: Next to them Jedaiah the son of Harumaph repaired opposite his house. And next to him Hattush the son of Hashabneiah repaired.
verses.comment: Repairing near one's home shows personal responsibility and involvement in the welfare of the community, a principle for all believers.

verses.text: Malchijah the son of Harim and Hasshub the son of Pahath-moab repaired another section and the Tower of the Ovens.
verses.comment: Multiple sections required multiple hands, again emphasizing the collective nature of the work, much like the many members of one Body (1 Cor. 12:12).

verses.text: Next to him Shallum the son of Hallohesh, leader of half the district of Jerusalem, repaired—he and his daughters.
verses.comment: Women take an active role in the restoration, reflecting the dignity and importance of all in the community of faith (cf. Acts 16:14–15).

verses.text: Hanun and the inhabitants of Zanoah repaired the Valley Gate. They rebuilt it and set up its doors, its bolts, and its bars, and repaired a thousand cubits of the wall to the Dung Gate.
verses.comment: Large-scale, difficult labor is shared, showing dedication and perseverance—a model for the perseverance required in spiritual life (James 1:12).

verses.text: Malchijah the son of Rechab, leader of the district of Beth-haccherem, repaired the Dung Gate. He rebuilt it and set up its doors, its bolts, and its bars.
verses.comment: Even the less-glamorous parts of the wall are repaired faithfully, signifying that all aspects of God's work are important, no matter how humble.

verses.text: And Shallun the son of Colhozeh, leader of the district of Mizpah, repaired the Fountain Gate. He rebuilt it, covered it, set up its doors, its bolts, and its bars, and he built the wall of the Pool of Shelah at the king’s garden, as far as the stairs that go down from the city of David.
verses.comment: The Pool of Shelah (Siloam) is later associated with Jesus’ miracle (John 9:7). The mention of water reflects the living water Jesus offers, connecting the Old and New Testament.

verses.text: After him Nehemiah the son of Azbuk, leader of half the district of Beth-zur, repaired as far as the tombs of David, as far as the artificial pool, and as far as the House of the Mighty Men.
verses.comment: References to the tombs of David and the House of the Mighty Men connect the restoration of Jerusalem to its spiritual heritage and the promise of David’s line (see Isa. 9:7).

verses.text: After him the Levites repaired: Rehum the son of Bani. Next to him Hashabiah, leader of half the district of Keilah, repaired for his district.
verses.comment: Levites, the priestly tribe, join in the physical as well as spiritual building, showing the harmony of service in God’s plan.

verses.text: After him their brothers repaired: Bavvai the son of Henadad, leader of half the district of Keilah.
verses.comment: Leadership at various levels is engaged in the work, pointing to the principle of apostolic succession and orderly governance in the assembly.

verses.text: Next to him Ezer the son of Jeshua, leader of Mizpah, repaired another section opposite the ascent to the armory at the Angle.
verses.comment: The mention of armory and the 'Angle' shows preparation and defense. There is a spiritual analogy of arming oneself for spiritual battle (Eph. 6:10–18).

verses.text: After him Baruch the son of Zabbai zealously repaired another section, from the Angle to the door of the house of Eliashib the high priest.
verses.comment: Special zeal in serving God benefits the whole community. Eliashib, as high priest, points to spiritual leadership and holiness (Heb. 7:26).

verses.text: After him Meremoth the son of Uriah, son of Hakkoz, repaired another section from the door of the house of Eliashib to the end of the house of Eliashib.
verses.comment: Continuity by multiple generations in the work of restoration reflects the passing down of faith and tradition.

verses.text: After him the priests, the men of the surrounding area, repaired.
verses.comment: Priests from outside Jerusalem also contribute, showing the universal calling of the faithful to God's service.

verses.text: After them Benjamin and Hasshub repaired opposite their house. After them Azariah the son of Maaseiah, son of Ananiah, repaired beside his house.
verses.comment: Again, work near one's home suggests familial participation and responsibility, resonating with the idea of each household serving the Lord (Josh. 24:15).

verses.text: After him Binnui the son of Henadad repaired another section, from the house of Azariah to the Angle and to the corner.
verses.comment: Repairing corners and angles symbolizes attention to detail and structural integrity in the life of faith.

verses.text: Palal the son of Uzai repaired opposite the Angle and the tower projecting from the upper house of the king, which is by the court of the guard. After him Pedaiah the son of Parosh repaired.
verses.comment: References to the king’s house and guard court reflect Jerusalem’s royal heritage and the intermingling of civil and holy responsibilities.

verses.text: Now the temple servants living in Ophel repaired to a point opposite the Water Gate on the east and the projecting tower.
verses.comment: Temple servants support the work, a reminder that various ministries, not just leadership, are essential to God's ongoing work.

verses.text: After them the Tekoites repaired another section opposite the great projecting tower as far as the wall of Ophel.
verses.comment: Persistence in labor is noted for the Tekoites, who complete additional sections, showing humble and tireless service.

verses.text: Above the Horse Gate the priests repaired, each one opposite his own house.
verses.comment: Priests are entrusted with sacred places, echoing the recurring principle that spiritual leaders are shepherds and maintainers.

verses.text: After them Zadok the son of Immer repaired opposite his own house. And after him Shemaiah the son of Shecaniah, the keeper of the East Gate, repaired.
verses.comment: Families and temple functionaries alike are part of full restoration; gates signify access to the presence of God.

verses.text: After him Hananiah the son of Shelemiah and Hanun the sixth son of Zalaph repaired another section. After him Meshullam the son of Berechiah repaired opposite his room.
verses.comment: Work continues down to individual rooms, showing the completeness of restoration, symbolizing God's desire to renew every part of life.

verses.text: After him Malchijah, one of the goldsmiths, repaired as far as the house of the temple servants and the merchants, opposite the Muster Gate, and as far as the upper chamber of the corner.
verses.comment: Economic workers, not just religious figures, have important roles. Their work is honored, showing the integration of faith and daily life.

verses.text: And between the upper chamber of the corner and the Sheep Gate, the goldsmiths and merchants repaired.
verses.comment: The rebuilding ends where it began, at the Sheep Gate, symbolizing restoration and unity—echoing the idea of one flock united under the Shepherd (John 10:11–16).
